---

### 1) **Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus**  
- **Citation / Link:** [Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)  
- **Published:** 04 June 2025 (Nature Neuroscience)  
- **Authors (first / last):** Sachin P. Vaidya … Jeffrey C. Magee  
- **Short description:** Tracks CA1 place cells across 7 days of learning and shows progressive increase in place-cell stability tied to behavioral-timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP). Proposes a cascade-like model where repeated activation increases the likelihood of neuron-specific synaptic plasticity rather than relying on permanent synaptic weight stabilization.  
- **Figure / image:**  
  ![Formation of an expanding memory representation — Fig1](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2) **Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons**  
- **Citation / Link:** [Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9)  
- **Published:** 18 December 2024 (Nature)  
- **Authors (first / last):** Kevin C. Gonzalez … Attila Losonczy  
- **Short description:** Develops an all-optical approach to monitor synaptic plasticity and spatiotemporal tuning at single-neuron resolution in awake behaving animals; links synaptic plasticity mechanisms to feature selectivity and place-field formation.  
- **Figure / image:**  
  ![Synaptic basis of feature selectivity — Fig1](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) **Systems consolidation reorganizes hippocampal engram circuitry**  
- **Citation / Link:** [Systems consolidation reorganizes hippocampal engram circuitry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-08993-1)  
- **Published:** 14 May 2025 (Nature)  
- **Authors (first / last):** Sangyoon Y. Ko … Paul W. Frankland  
- **Short description:** Shows time-dependent rewiring of hippocampal engram circuits during systems consolidation; links circuit reorganization to changes in memory precision and generalization—implicates synaptic reorganization/plasticity across time.  
- **Figure / image:**  
  ![Systems consolidation reorganizes hippocampal engram circuitry — Fig1](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-025-08993-1/MediaObjects/41586_2025_8993_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 4) **Bidirectional synaptic plasticity rapidly modifies hippocampal representations**  
- **Citation / Link / DOI:** [Bidirectional synaptic plasticity rapidly modifies hippocampal representations — eLife (2021)](https://elifesciences.org/articles/73046) — DOI: 10.7554/eLife.73046  
- **Published:** 09 Dec 2021 (eLife)  
- **Authors (first / last):** Aaron D. Milstein … Sandro Romani / Jeffrey C. Magee (coauthors)  
- **Short description:** Investigates a form of synaptic plasticity driven by dendritic plateau potentials and shows how bidirectional plasticity rapidly alters hippocampal representations (place fields). Open access.  
- **Figure / image:**  
  ![eLife article icon](https://elifesciences.org/assets/images/social/icon-600x600@1.52e87ee6.png)

---

### 5) **Synaptic plasticity rules driving representational shifting in the hippocampus**  
- **Citation / Link:** [Synaptic plasticity rules driving representational shifting in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01894-6)  
- **Published:** 20 March 2025 (Nature Neuroscience)  
- **Authors (first / last):** Mark E. J. Sheffield (author noted)  
- **Short description:** The article discusses rules of synaptic plasticity that underlie shifts in hippocampal representations; includes review-style references and contextualization of LTP/LTD, spike timing, and heterosynaptic/homeostatic processes.  
- **Figure / image:**  
  ![Synaptic plasticity rules — Fig1](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01894-6/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1894_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 6) **Entorhinal cortex directs learning-related changes in CA1 representations**  
- **Citation / Link:** [Entorhinal cortex directs learning-related changes in CA1 representations](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05378-6)  
- **Published:** 02 Nov 2022 (Nature)  
- **Authors (first / last):** Jeffrey C. Magee (senior author)  
- **Short description:** Shows that learning-related over-representation in CA1 requires BTSP and that entorhinal cortex layer 3 activity provides an instructive signal directing BTSP; supports the idea of long-range input gating synaptic plasticity in hippocampal place-field formation.  
- **Figure / image:**  
  ![Entorhinal cortex directs learning-related changes — Fig1](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-022-05378-6/MediaObjects/41586_2022_5378_Fig1_HTML.png)

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
```

To show accurate, up-to-date usage of the Entity SDK for listing cell morphologies, I'll fetch the official EntitySDK documentation and examples for the relevant API calls and client patterns. With that documentation I can provide a ready-to-run Python example using the SDK.## Overview

First create an authenticated EntitySDK client and project context. Next run a typed search for **CellMorphology** entities, choose whether to iterate results (stream) or fetch pages (.all()), and apply filters such as brain region or species. Below are concise, ready-to-run examples and notes.

### Quick plan
- Create the **Client** with a project context and token.  
- Search for **CellMorphology** using `client.search_entity(...)`.  
- Handle pagination either by iterating the returned iterator or using `.all()` to fetch all hits.  
- Apply filters (brain region, species) via the `query` dictionary and access fields (`id`, `name`, `brain_region`, `subject.species.name`).

---

## Example: Minimal setup and listing morphologies

```python
import os
from uuid import UUID
from entitysdk.client import Client
from entitysdk.common import ProjectContext
from entitysdk.models import CellMorphology

# Authentication + project context (replace with your values or env vars)
API_URL = os.getenv(\ENTITYCORE_API_URL", \https://entitycore.openbraininstitute.org")
PROJECT_ID = UUID(os.getenv(\PROJECT_ID", \00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000"))
VIRTUAL_LAB_ID = UUID(os.getenv(\VIRTUAL_LAB_ID", \00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000"))
TOKEN = os.getenv(\ACCESS_TOKEN", \your-access-token")

project_context = ProjectContext(project_id=PROJECT_ID, virtual_lab_id=VIRTUAL_LAB_ID)
client = Client(api_url=API_URL, project_context=project_context, token_manager=TOKEN)
```

Notes:
- Use the correct API URL and valid UUIDs for your project and virtual lab.
- The token can be taken from environment variables or other token manager used by your deployment.

---

## Example A — Stream results (memory efficient)

This uses the iterator returned by `client.search_entity(...)`. It’s suitable when the result set may be large.

```python
iterator = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={},   # optional filters go here
    limit=None  # None means no hard limit; iterate until exhausted
)

for morph in iterator:
    print(\ID:", morph.id)
    print(\Name:", morph.name)
    # Access nested fields if present
    print(\Brain region:", getattr(morph,  rain_region", None))
    # subject may be nested; guard for missing attributes:
    subject = getattr(morph, \subject", None)
    species_name = None
    if subject is not None:
        species_name = getattr(getattr(subject, \species", None), 
ame", None)
    print(\Subject species:", species_name)
    print("---")
```

---

## Example B — Fetch all results (convenient, but potentially memory-heavy)

Use `.all()` when you expect a moderate number of results and want them available as a list.

```python
hits = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={},       # filters (see next section)
    limit=None
).all()

print(\Total hits:", len(hits))
for morph in hits:
    print(morph.id, morph.name)
```

---

## Filtering examples

Use the `query` dictionary to pass API filters. Common keys (from SDK examples):

- Case-insensitive name match:
  - `
ame__ilike": \pyramidal%"`
- Filter by brain region label (path used in examples):
  - ` rain_location__brain_region__label": \Primary motor cortex"`
- Filter by species label:
  - `\subject__species__label": \Mus musculus"`
- Pagination parameters (if you prefer page-by-page):
  - `\page": 1`, `\page_size": 50`

Example: filter by brain region and species:

```python
query = {
     rain_location__brain_region__label": \Primary motor cortex",
    \subject__species__label": \Mus musculus",
    \page": 1,
    \page_size": 50
}

iterator = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query=query, limit=None)
for morph in iterator:
    print(morph.id, morph.name)
```

---

## Accessing returned fields reliably

Because some fields may be absent, use defensive attribute access:

- `morph.id` — unique identifier (UUID string)
- `morph.name` — morphology name
- `morph.description` — optional
- `morph.brain_region` or nested `morph.brain_location.brain_region` — depending on schema returned; inspect the object structure
- `morph.subject.species.name` — species (guard for None at each level)

Pattern to read nested fields safely:

```python
def get_nested(obj, *attrs):
    cur = obj
    for a in attrs:
        if cur is None:
            return None
        cur = getattr(cur, a, None)
    return cur

species_name = get_nested(morph, \subject", \species", 
ame")
brain_region_label = get_nested(morph,  rain_location",  rain_region", \label")
```

---

## Pagination notes and total count

- The iterator approach streams results and avoids manual paging.  
- The `.all()` convenience will fetch all results (respect `page`/`page_size` behind the scenes).  
- If you need to know `total_items` or to control pages explicitly, include `page` and `page_size` in `query` and inspect returned page metadata if the SDK exposes it (SDK examples show using `page` + `page_size` in `query`).

---

## Helpful tips

- Start with small `page_size` during development to inspect returned object fields and decide which nested keys exist in your environment.

pricing_simulation_costs.user: How much does it cost to run simulations on the platform?
pricing_simulation_costs.expected_output:
## Simulation Costs

Simulation costs depend on your plan (Free or Pro) and the type of simulation you're running.

### Simulation Costs by Plan

| Simulation Type | Free Plan | Pro Plan |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|
| **E-model** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Ion channel** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Single cell** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Synaptome** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Small microcircuit** (≤10 neurons) | 10 credits/simulation | 5 credits/simulation |
| **Microcircuit** (>10 neurons) | 0.05 credits/neuron/second of biological time | 0.025 credits/neuron/second of biological time |

### Credits Included

- **Free Plan:** 100 free initial credits (expire in 1 year)
- **Pro Plan Monthly:** 50 free credits/month (CHF 25/month)
- **Pro Plan Yearly:** 650 free credits/year (CHF 275/year)

### Cost Savings with Pro

The Pro plan offers approximately **50% cost reduction** on all simulation types:
- Basic simulations: 0.5 vs 1 credit
- Small microcircuits: 5 vs 10 credits
- Large microcircuits: Half the per-neuron cost

### Example Calculations

- **10 single cell simulations on Free:** 10 credits
- **10 single cell simulations on Pro:** 5 credits
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Free:** 5 credits (100 × 0.05)
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Pro:** 2.5 credits (100 × 0.025)

Source: OBI pricing plans (Sanity planV2).

cerebellum_morphologies.ai_response:
I will first resolve the brain region name \cerebellum\ to the platform's brainregion ID so I can search morphologies within that region. Next, I'll query cell morphologies using that brainregion ID and request 5 items. Now I'll find the brain region ID for \cerebellum".Now that the cerebellum brainregion ID is known, I'll query cell morphologies within that region and request five items to return a concise set.## Results — 5 cerebellum morphologies (page 1 of results)

I first resolved \cerebellum\ to the platform brainregion ID **062ebc92-cebb-498a-a76d-b5ef1baf02cf**, then fetched the first 5 cell morphologies within that region. The search returned **total_items: 66** morphologies in the Cerebellum; here are the five returned on page 1:

---

### 1) soma_10c  
- **ID:** **e892fa95-c724-457a-8dc6-176f5d6cc5d9**  
- **Description:** Soma flask-like (~7.5 µm) in Purkinje cell layer; large, highly branched flat dendritic tree in molecular layer; single long axon projecting to white matter — the principal output neuron of the cerebellum.  
- **MType:** *CBXpu_PuC* (Cerebellum Purkinje Cell)  
- **Assets (file names / content types):**
  - soma_10c.swc (application/swc)
  - soma_10c.h5 (application/x-hdf5)
  - soma_10c.asc (application/asc)  
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0  
- **Entity link:** [View morphology details](https://openbraininstitute.org/app/entity/e892fa95-c724-457a-8dc6-176f5d6cc5d9)

---

### 2) 01bc  
- **ID:** **d083a0bd-00a4-4594-b52f-950a5dd3ec70**  
- **Description:** Soma pyramidal/oval (~6 µm) in inner molecular layer; long straight dendrites to pia with few branches; axon runs parallel to Purkinje cell layer with descending and ascending collaterals.  
- **MType:** *CBXmo_BC* (Cerebellum Basket Cell)  
- **Assets:**
  - 01bc.swc (application/swc)
  - 01bc.h5 (application/x-hdf5)
  - 01bc.asc (application/asc)  
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0  
- **Entity link:** [View morphology details](https://openbraininstitute.org/app/entity/d083a0bd-00a4-4594-b52f-950a5dd3ec70)

---

### 3) stellate  
- **ID:** **00ba95d3-13e4-4703-ad85-3df816febf53**  
- **Description:** Small fusiform soma (~4 µm) in outer molecular layer; long, thin, contorted, aspinous dendrites branching in all directions; axon branches immediately into short collaterals.  
- **MType:** *CBXmo_StC* (Cerebellum Stellate Cell)  
- **Assets:**
  - stellate.swc (application/swc)
  - stellate.h5 (application/x-hdf5)
  - stellate.asc (application/asc)  
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0  
- **Entity link:** [View morphology details](https://openbraininstitute.org/app/entity/00ba95d3-13e4-4703-ad85-3df816febf53)

---

### 4) pair-140514-C2-1_split_1  
- **ID:** **cb635d11-f5f4-4ec5-8c6e-3e5af6d4eb6c**  
- **Description:** Soma round/polygonal (~8 µm) in granular layer; 4–10 dendrites split into basal (remain in granular layer) and apical (ascend to molecular layer, fan-shaped). Axons thin, beaded, forming extensive axon plexus in granular layer.  
- **MType:** *CBXgr_GoC* (Cerebellum Golgi Cell)  
- **Assets:**
  - pair-140514-C2-1_split_1.swc (application/swc)
  - pair-140514-C2-1_split_1.h5 (application/x-hdf5)

---

### 5) GrC2018  
- **ID:** **b03ceac9-d657-488c-a43c-01be275d0861**  
- **Description:** Very small soma (~2.5 µm) in granular layer; 4–5 dendrites ending in claw-like appendages. Axon ascends to molecular layer and bifurcates into parallel fibers running along folium axis.  
- **MType:** *CBXgr_GrC* (Cerebellum Granule Cell)  
- **Assets:**
  - GrC2018.swc (application/swc)
  - GrC2018.h5 (application/x-hdf5)
  - GrC2018.asc (application/asc)  
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
To find recent, relevant papers I will run a focused literature search for studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum (last few years) to capture experimental and computational work; the results will let me summarize key findings and provide DOIs/links for each paper.## Quick summary — recent notable studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum

Below are recent, high-impact studies (2021–2025) that analyze single‑neuron morphology, dendrite/axon architectures, or large-scale morphometric mapping in cerebral cortex / forebrain regions. Each entry includes the article title, citation/link, a brief takeaway, and the paper image when provided by the search results.

### 1) Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry (2024)
- **Citation:** Yufeng Liu et al., *Nature Communications* (2024).  
- **Link / DOI:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6  
- **Takeaway:** Whole‑brain morphometry across many neurons to quantify morphological diversity and stereotypy at multiple spatial scales; useful for understanding large-scale anatomical variation across forebrain regions.
- ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 2) Single‑neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex (2023)
- **Citation:** Le Gao et al., *Nature Neuroscience* 26:1111–1126 (2023).  
- **Link / DOI:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01339-y  
- **Takeaway:** Complete dendrite and axon reconstructions of ~2,000 PFC neurons; identifies many dendritic subtypes among pyramidal neurons and links somatodendritic scaling to cytoarchitecture and projection patterns — valuable for circuit reconstruction in prefrontal cortex.  
- ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-023-01339-y/MediaObjects/41593_2023_1339_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 3) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex (2025)
- **Citation:** Marissa A. Weis et al., *Nature Communications* (2025).  
- **Link / DOI:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w  
- **Takeaway:** Unsupervised mapping of dendritic shapes among excitatory neurons in visual cortex; offers a morphology-driven taxonomy that can support structure–function analyses in visual areas.  
- ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 4) Morphological diversity of single neurons in molecularly defined cell types (2021)
- **Citation:** Hanchuan Peng et al., *Nature* 598:174 (2021).  
- **Link / DOI:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-021-03941-1  
- **Takeaway:** Large‑scale pipeline reconstructing >1,700 single neurons brain‑wide (including cortex); compares morphological diversity with transcriptomic cell types and outlines principles of projection diversity across forebrain areas.  
- (No image provided in the search result excerpt.)

### 5) Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro‑ and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy (preprint / eLife reviewed preprint, 2024)
- **Citation:** Hernando et al., *eLife* reviewed preprint (2024).  
- **Link / DOI / preprint:** https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/99688v2  
- **Takeaway:** Very large, anatomically detailed model of juvenile rat neocortex including 4.2M morphologically detailed neurons and 14.2B synapses — relevant for morphology‑driven circuit modeling and limitations of inferring connectivity from shape/placement.  
- (No image provided in the search result excerpt.)

### 6) Cell class‑specific long‑range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker‑related somatosensory cortices (eLife reviewed preprint, 2024)
- **Citation:** Aronoff & Petersen, *eLife* reviewed preprint (2024).  
- **Link / DOI / preprint:** https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/97602v1/pdf  
- **Takeaway:** Brain‑wide light‑sheet imaging + automated axon segmentation to quantify layer‑ and class‑specific long‑range outputs from somatosensory cortex — useful for mapping projection patterns of defined cortical cell classes.

---

## Short synthesis and themes
- Recent work moves beyond small sample sizes to thousands of reconstructed neurons, enabling unsupervised morphological atlases and direct comparisons to transcriptomic or electrophysiological classes.
- Papers focus both on local dendritic/axonal structure (e.g., prefrontal cortex) and whole‑brain or large‑scale morphometry that reveal principles of projection diversity.
- There is increasing integration of morphology with other modalities (transcriptomics, electrophysiology, functional imaging) and efforts to use morphology for improved circuit reconstruction and large‑scale modeling.

Given these results, the next step will be to fetch full‑text content for any papers you want read in detail so I can extract methods, figures, or specific metrics (e.g., dendritic length, branching statistics, laminar distributions).

Would you like me to:
- Read the full text of any specific paper above (I can attempt to extract the full article where publicly available), or
- Return additional recent papers (more results, different years, or other cerebral subregions such as motor cortex, somatosensory, or hippocampal cortex)?

me_model_glossary.ai_response:
To provide the platform's exact glossary definition, I'll query the Open Brain Platform glossary for the term that matches \ME-model\ so I can return the authoritative description and any related details. Next, I'll retrieve glossary entries containing \ME-model".## Definition (platform glossary)

**ME-model**

**Definition:** An **ME-model**, or *morphoelectric model*, is a combination of an **E-model** (electrical model) with the relevant neuronal **morphology**. ME-models can be simulated using **BlueCelluLab** and serve as essential elements in circuit building.

- **Short form:** ME-model = E-model + morphology  
- **Primary use:** Single-neuron simulations and as building blocks for circuits (e.g., synaptome or circuit simulations)  
- **Simulation tool mentioned:** **BlueCelluLab** ([BlueCelluLab](https://github.com/openbraininstitute/BlueCelluLab))

Source: Open Brain Platform glossary (queried entries — total_items: **4**).

software_docs_obione.user: Please show me a code example of how to create a single cell simulation using the obione package.
software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Single-cell simulation example (Python, using obi_one)

- **Goal:** configure a single-cell MEModel simulation: a somatic constant current clamp, soma voltage recording, initialize with a MEModel ID, validate the configuration.
- Replace **ME_MODEL_UUID** with your MEModel UUID (or a circuit UUID as required).

```python
# Single-cell simulation using obi_one (MEModel)
# Replace the ME model ID below with the actual UUID for your MEModel
# (e.g., \123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000")

import obi_one as obi
from pathlib import Path

# -------------------------
# Parameters
# -------------------------
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms
me_model_id = \ME_MODEL_UUID\  # <-- REPLACE with your MEModel UUID

# -------------------------
# Create an empty MEModel simulation config
# -------------------------
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Metadata / info
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\Single-cell MEModel Example",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell simulation: somatic current clamp + soma voltage recording"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info")

# Define regular timestamps (used by stimuli if desired)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(
    start_time=0.0,
    number_of_repetitions=1,
    interval=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name=egular_timestamps")

# -------------------------
# Stimulus: somatic constant current clamp
# -------------------------
# Single amplitude (nA) example. Use a list for scan/parameter sweep.
cc_stim = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    delay=10.0,       # ms before stimulus onset
    duration=200.0,   # ms duration of current injection
    amplitude=0.5     # nA (use [0.2, 0.5] for scan across amplitudes)
)
sim_conf.add(cc_stim, name=\constant_current_soma")

# -------------------------
# Recording: soma voltage (full time window)
# -------------------------
voltage_rec = obi.SomaVoltageRecording(
    neuron_set=None,    # For MEModel single-cell simulations, default references typically suffice
    start_time=0.0,
    end_time=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.add(voltage_rec, name=\soma_voltage")

# -------------------------
# Initialization: point to the MEModel
# -------------------------
# Use MEModelFromID to reference an existing MEModel in the EntityCore knowledge graph.
me_model_ref = obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=me_model_id)

initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=me_model_ref,
    simulation_length=sim_duration,
    v_init=-80.0,   # initial membrane potential (mV)
    random_seed=42
)
sim_conf.set(initialize, name=\initialize")

# -------------------------
# Validate the configuration
# -------------------------
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()

# Inspect the validated configuration (prints a structured representation)
print(\Validated simulation configuration:")
print(validated_sim_conf)
```
